Award.AwardTitle: INFEWS: N/P/H20: From Antinutrients to Water Pollutants: Exploring the Behavior of Polyphosphate Anions in Aqueous Solutions
Award.AbstractNarration:
Phytate is a common molecule found in the husks of corn, as well as other plant materials. Its presence in food can interfere with the adsorption of nutrients in the digestive track of many animals, including pigs and chickens. As a result, proteins and vital metal ions present in the animals' feed are rendered unavailable, causing an enormous loss in efficiency in the meat products made from these animals. With the support from the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the NSF Chemistry Division, Prof. Paul S. Cremer at the Pennsylvania State University is studying phytate and similar anions (molecules with extra negative charge) to understand their interactions with metal ions and to learn how these highly negatively charged species cause the precipitation of proteins and other large molecules from water solutions. This work not only helps shed light on how livestock feed can be used more efficiently, but also helps train graduate and undergraduate students in the chemical sciences. Simplified versions of these studies are being used as a springboard to update the curriculum and laboratories used to teach high school students about intermolecular forces and non-covalent interactions.

The Cremer group is exploring interactions between phytate and divalent metal cations in aqueous solutions. The interactions between various cations and individual phosphate groups are often similar, but this changes markedly when metal ions interact simultaneously with multiple phosphate groups, where the ions can bridge adjacent phosphate moieties. The thermodynamics of ion binding is being correlated with information on the polyanion's hydration shell that can be obtained by Raman and vibrational sum frequency spectroscopy. Such studies are also being extended to understand how ion binding and hydration water structures affect the salting out of proteins and polypeptides from aqueous solutions as a function of pH, salt concentration, and specific cation identity. In addition to phytate, which contains six phosphate groups around an inositol ring, studies are being performed with one through five phosphate groups placed around the ring with specific stereochemistry. Measurements are also being made with phosphatidylinositol lipids in planar membrane formats to elucidate the difference in binding behavior of polyphosphate groups bound to surfaces and those in bulk solution.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on the behavior of phosphate and polyphosphate anions in aqueous solutions with particular attention to their water structure, ion pairing behavior, and to the behavior of phosphate moieties on lipids like phosphatidylinositols. Phosphate is a well-hydrated anion and is excluded from hydrophobic interfaces. It binds to cations in aqueous solutions with equilibrium dissociation constants generally in the millimolar to micromolecular concentration range depending upon the specific conditions. The behavior of anions, including phosphate, can be rank ordered according to their ion specific effects on numerous physical properties of the system, such as their ability to solubilize proteins and polymers. This ordering, known as the Hofmeister series, depends on an ion's size, charge, geometry, the counterions present, and other related variables. In the current project, it was found that phosphate's properties are strongly influenced by the formation of hydrogen bonds between the oxygen atoms on the anion and hydrogen bond donors from the surrounding aqueous solution. For example, PI(4,5)P2, a phosphatidylinositol lipid with three phosphate groups, will hydrogen bond to protein-coated or inorganic surfaces that donate hydrogen bonds, even when those surfaces bear a net negative charge. This behavior is subject to an isotope effect and the anion's interactions become stronger in D2O compared to H2O.

Another key finding from this work involves the behavior of phosphate moieties on the lipid headgroups of phosphatidylcholine lipids. The interfacial water structure near these headgroups is dominated by the interactions of phosphate with positively charged choline groups on adjacent lipids. When low concentrations of excess positive charge are introduced to the system (e.g. Ca2+ or positively charged surfactants), they disrupt the interfacial hydration structure and reorient the phosphatidylcholine headgroup toward the surface normal. By contrast, the introduction of negative charge leaves the phosphate hydrogen bonding network at the membrane/water interface intact and even helps increase water ordering.

A third key finding of this project concerns the binding of phosphate moieties to divalent metal cations. In particular, Ca2+ and Zn2+ readily form contact ion pairs with phosphate. Other ions, like Mg2+, form solvent shared ion pairs with phosphate because it is less favorable for Mg2+ to shed its hydration shell. The contact ion pairing, especially with Zn2+, can bridge across phosphate moieties leading, for example, to membrane curvature when phosphatidylserine lipids are present.

The presence of well-hydrated anions in an aqueous system, like phosphate and sulfate, was also shown to influence the hydration of weakly hydrated anions like iodide. That is because well-hydrated anions swipe counterions, like Na+, away from the more poorly hydrated anion. This leaves the more poorly hydrated anion better hydrated, which will make it behave more like a strongly hydrated anion. This is a non-additive effect, whereby mixtures of charged species in solution lead to behavior that is not simply the sum of the individual behaviors. Additional non-additive effects were found during the course of this study, like the generic pairing of salt ions in solution. Interestingly, these effects can lead to either enhanced salting-in or salting-out behavior for polymers in solution, depending on whether the ion pairing is enriched at the interface or depleted from it.

Beyond the specific research findings associated with this project, there were a number of significant broader impacts. Specifically, this project helped to train graduate students in cross-disciplinary areas that involved biophysical chemistry, spectroscopy, polymer chemistry, and materials chemistry. Moreover, an outreach component of this project helped to develop simple laboratory experiments for 10th and 11th grade high school classrooms that involved understanding the properties of water, polymer hydration, and specific ion effects. Worksheets for the laboratory were devised and videos were made and posted for public use. These experiments were developed with the help of high school chemistry teachers.
